Class Thanksgiving

  • java.lang.Object
    • Thanksgiving

  • public class Thanksgiving
extends java.lang.Object
    Thanksgiving class This Class contains quicksort(), binarySearch(), and a recursive method eatTurkey(), to sort Turkeys, search a specific turkey and eat that Turkey.
    Author:
    Sanchita Kanade

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      Thanksgiving() 

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Static Methods Concrete Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      static int binarySearch(int key, java.util.ArrayList<Turkey> turkeys)
      This method searchs an ArrayList of Turkey objects, and returns the index of the Turkey by a specified weight.
      static void eatTurkey(Turkey t)
      This method recursively eats a turkey, by subtracting 1 lb of turkey for each recursive call.
      static void main(java.lang.String[] args)
      This method creates an ArrayList of Turkey objects and calls quicksort(), binarySearch() and eatTurkey() methods.
      static int partition(java.util.ArrayList<Turkey> turkeys, int i, int k)
      This method partitions the input into low and high parts.
      static void quicksort(java.util.ArrayList<Turkey> turkeys, int i, int k)
      This method sorts the ArrayList of Turkey objects by weight (lowest to highest), using Quick sort algorithm.

    • Method Detail

      • quicksort

        public static void quicksort(java.util.ArrayList<Turkey> turkeys,
                             int i,
                             int k)
        This method sorts the ArrayList of Turkey objects by weight (lowest to highest), using Quick sort algorithm. I choose this sorting algorithm, because runtime for both Selection sort and Insertion sort is O(n2)[Big-O of n squared], on the other hand runtime for Quick sort algorith is O(n log n). Hence, Quick sort have faster execution time than Selection and Insertion sort. Moreover, in this case there is no unequal partitioning at every level during sorting, so it is not the worst case for Quick sort algorithm and runtime for Quick sort algorith is O(n log n). Merge sort algorithm's runtime is also O(n log n), but it requires additional memory to store elements in temporary array, hence Quick sort algorithm is efficient in this case. I write this code with the help of learn.zybooks.com and passed ArrayList of turkey objects to partition and quicksort methods as a parameter.
        Parameters:
        turkeys - represents ArrayList of turkeys.
        i - represents the lowest index of an ArrayList.
        k - represents the highest index of an ArrayList.

      • partition

        public static int partition(java.util.ArrayList<Turkey> turkeys,
                            int i,
                            int k)
        This method partitions the input into low and high parts.
        Parameters:
        turkeys - represents ArrayList of turkeys.
        i - represents the lowest index of an ArrayList.
        k - represents the highest index of an ArrayList.
        Returns:
        h represents the index of the last element in the low partition.

      • binarySearch

        public static int binarySearch(int key,
                               java.util.ArrayList<Turkey> turkeys)
        This method searchs an ArrayList of Turkey objects, and returns the index of the Turkey by a specified weight.
        Parameters:
        key - represents weight of Turkey.
        turkeys - represents ArrayList of turkeys.
        Returns:
        an index of the Turkey. refered www.coursera.org and zybooks to write this code.

      • eatTurkey

        public static void eatTurkey(Turkey t)
        This method recursively eats a turkey, by subtracting 1 lb of turkey for each recursive call.
        Parameters:
        t - represents Turkey object.

      • main

        public static void main(java.lang.String[] args)
        This method creates an ArrayList of Turkey objects and calls quicksort(), binarySearch() and eatTurkey() methods.
        Parameters:
        args - command-line arguments
